nodes.body:
Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8084198746/job/22088948572)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8084198746/job/22088948301)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8084198746/job/22088948077)

Thanks for the forward port! I'm trying to pitch in with a review as someone with an interest in CGT. This is indeed a faithful forward port of the pgame.lean changes in leanprover-community/mathlib#15260, so while I do have some requested changes, I don't mind if we merge this and save my feedback for a future PR.
LGTM. Thanks! I have one question/non-blocking suggestion

I'm hesitant about this definition. If it's just a helper definition for proving `bddAbove_of_small`, I don't mind it, although I imagine that `â¨Î¹, PEmpty, f, PEmpty.elimâ©` would be easier to work with. If this is supposed to be a useful canonical definition of an upper bound for pre-games, I think it's a suboptimal one to choose. One desirable property of a canonical upper bound is that it is the least upper bound if one exists. This definition does not satisfy that property. (e.g. upperBound {0, 1/2} = upperBound {{ | }, {0 | 1}} = {0 | } = 1 â  1/2.)

Would it be reasonable to request that this definition and any required lemmas for it be inlined into the proof of `bddAbove_of_small`? (And perhaps the proof can even be golfed by changing the definition to `â¨Î¹, PEmpty, f, PEmpty.elimâ©`)

Alternatively, if we can think of a simple upper bound definition that does take on the least upper bound when possible, I would be happy to see that used to prove `bddAbove_of_small` instead.

This is a specialization of `bddAbove_of_small` to `small_range`. (Although the `small_range` instance is not currently in scope because we only import `Logic.Small.Defs`.) Is it really worth exposing as a separate lemma? I suppose the benefit of having it as a seperate lemma is that it makes the proof of `bddAbove_of_small` more modular. This seems like a tradeoff between API clutter and proof modularity. What is the usual stance on this tradeoff in mathlib? Maybe we can get the best of both worlds by marking this as a `private lemma`?

On the other hand, maybe this lemma is good for searchability? A user might be expecting to prove `BddAbove` via a family and not know what `Small` means so fail to identify that `bddAbove_of_small` is applicable?

Most predicates in mathlib come in two kinds: A set version and an indexed version. You can define `IsFooSet s` as `IsFooFamily (Subtype.val : s â Î±)` and you can define `IsFooFamily f` as `IsFooSet (Set.range f)` (assuming duplicates in your family don't matter). However, it is usually impractical to use one predicate in place of the other:
* When using `IsFooFamily (Subtype.val : s â Î±)`, elements of `s` are now images of the coercion `Subtype.val : s â Î±`
* When using `IsFooSet (Set.range f)`, you need to replace `y â Set.range f` by `f x`, `x` and vice-versa.

It is therefore preferrable to have both predicates (see eg `IsDirected`). This is currently not the case for `BddAbove`, where we only have the set version. Hence I am acting as if `BddAbove (Set.range _)` was a predicate, because many lemmas expect it in that form and because it might become one in the future. The fact that `bddAbove_range_of_small` can be syntactically derived from `bddAbove_of_small` is somehow an accident of us not having the family predicate, and I would rather not muddle the waters by only having the set version of the lemma.
No need to point out everything twice. Despite contrary claims, I am in fact not a LLM ð

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(SetTheory): Upper bound for games
